repnme.cdata!:
Turkey - Road Improvement and Traffic
            Safety Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Road Improvement and Traffic Safety
            Project for Turkey was selected for assessment due to the
            difference of opinion between the implementing agency and
            the Bank on project implementation issues and to review the
            impact of the traffic safety component.  The report furthers
            the knowledge base on road safety programs, as well as
            governance and institutional issues in the transport sector.
            It agrees with the completion report in all ratings except
            that the outcome is judged to be moderately satisfactory
            instead of satisfactory.  Three important lessons may be
            drawn from the project: A) Improvements in governance can
            best be achieved when there is a holistic program of
            institutional reform mandated at the highest levels of
            government, with interactive communication with operational
            staff to ensure that the changes take place in the field as
            envisioned. B) Traffic safety projects can be particularly
            successful where there is strong government commitment and
            support and where a participatory approach is pursued to
            ensure the support of all the diverse stakeholders.  C) The
            elimination of road accident black spots can be a highly
            cost effective way to reduce both the accident rate and the
            degree of severity of the accidents occurring.

TF031968-TURKEY - ROAD

repnme.cdata!:
Turkey - Road Improvement & Traffic
            Safety Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the Road Improvement and
            Traffic Safety Project for Turkey were as follows: the
            outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact was modest, and the Bank
            and borrower performance were both satisfactory. The lessons
            learned indicate that in looking back at the experience
            gathered through this project, there are two major areas
            where lessons emerge: (i) the successful implementation of a
            rather complex traffic safety component involving several
            agencies; and, (ii) the approach taken by the project to
            influence governance issues in a sector prone to capture by
            strong vested interests. In particular: The Traffic Safety
            Experience - the design of this component was, from the
            outset, the result of a participatory exercise in which each
            organization involved in the project brought its own
            perspective to the traffic safety problem and proposed its
            own solutions. The individualistic approach to the issues at
            stake slowly evolved into a collegial system structured
            under the Task Force that was the key player in the
            implementation of the component. This accomplishment, not a
            minor feat in a country not known for inter-agency
            coordination, can be attributed to the adoption of the
            "best fit" rather than "best practice"
            approach. The Governance Issue - the project was prepared at
            a time in which the structural issues of governance were not
            as clearly recognized as today, maybe confusing capabilities
            (or lack thereof) with rent seeking behavior, and proposing
            institutional development rather than major policy reforms.
            The Bank's position of not participating in the
            financing, and therefore not condoning, the practice of
            continuous changes of design and cost overruns, was a step
            in the right direction given the relationship with Turkey at
            the time. A related question from which it might be possible
            to draw some useful lessons refers to the Bank's
            decision to deny a Government request to extend the life of
            the loan. At that time substantial human and financial costs
            had been sunk in the preparation of a fairly sophisticated
            Highway Information System.

repnme.cdata!:
Turkey - Road Improvement and Traffic
            Safety Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Road Improvement
            and Traffic Safety Project include: 1) reduction of road
            transport costs through infrastructure improvements and
            protection of past investments in the highway sector through
            rehabilitation and strengthening of paved highways; 2)
            improvement of traffic safety in state and provincial roads;
            3) improvement of the operational efficiency of the General
            Directorate of Highways (KGM) through the implementation of
            management systems and computerization; and 4) improvement
            in the consideration of environmental factors in project
            selection and design. The components of the project are the
            following: 1) road improvement program, comprising
            strengthening or upgrading of about 600 kilometers of high
            priority state roads, about 300 kilometers of rural
            (provincial) roads and town passages; 2) road traffic safety
            program, involving: (a) civil and traffic engineering
            improvements to accident black spots; (b) a program to
            improve driver education; (c) provision of equipment to the
            Turkish traffic police (TTP) and the medical hospital at
            Gazi University; (d) extension of TTP's accident data
            base to other users; and (e) provision of road safety
            materials for traffic management; and 3) institutional
            development program, consisting in the introduction of
            various management systems and computerization throughout
            KGM and training of the staff of KGM in the areas of
            environmental analysis, road planning, construction and maintenance.
